Now there are some funny moments and it is really a pleasure to see a very NICE character in the lead, but just not enough laughs to keep the audiences coming back. Kevin James stars (and helped write) here as Paul Blart, who ended up as a mall cap because he couldn't control his blood sugar levels, and passed out during the state trooper camp. The bit here is that he takes his mall job very seriously and to no one's surprise, is a loser in love.

I found his initial physical attraction to kiosk salesperson Jayman Mays (Epic Movie) a bit ironic ... since there are so many jokes about James' weight. I can only assume that Mays' performance is so over the top bad because that's what director Steve Carr (Daddy Day Care) takes has humor. Better support work was delivered by Keir O'Donnell (very funny in Wedding Crashers), Bobby Cannavale and the very classy Shirley Knight as James' mom.

Kevin James is talented and he likes to compare himself to Jackie Gleason, Chris Farley and John Belushi - other comedy "heavy weights". After Mall Cop, Hitch, and Chuck and Larry, he is still searching for just the right movie vehicle to compliment his TV success on King of Queens.
The carb movie. All humor deals with carbs/sugar. It was huge back in the day when this movie came out.

You'd think that a role like this was perfect for Kevin James. A lovable loser who's security guard at the mall. His wife left him and he's yet to get back into the dating scene.

I like Kevin James in other things, but this movie just wasn't funny or all that entertaining. This movie hinged on Kevin James' character and he couldn't make it work. There were a couple of chuckle moments but it was mostly uncomfortably unhumorous.

I think James did OK with what he was given to work with. This was simply a case of getting less than I expected. It happens from time to time and it's always annoying.

review_title: Psychotic thief threatening to kill hostages--this is supposed to be funny?

I find Kevin James hilarious in just about everything he does, and frankly, this looked like a pretty decent setup for a "dumb comedy" (I love dumb comedies, so that's not an insult in the least.) However, though this certainly had its funny moments, as a whole it really did not fit together as I found myself wondering if I were watching a Home Alone-reminiscent comedy about an under-appreciated maul guard protecting his mall in humorous ways or something serious. Not a good thing to be wondering.

It began well. It wanted to be good. However, there was a little too much exposition before the mall was actually taken over by baddies. All right, now the rest is funny stuff. But it seemed that most of the funny stuff was what was in the trailer, leaving us with awkward hit-and-miss humor and clumsy action.

And then they started threatening people. And then Paul Blart's daughter got involved. And I started thinking "This is pretty scary for a PG comedy". Seriously, folks, these people were hostages. There was a little girl. Discussing shooting them dead isn't very funny.

It was well-intentioned, this movie was. Don't get me wrong. But the ingredients were, frankly, a mess.

I'll stick with "King of Queens" reruns. It's funny and they don't threaten to kill people on it.

review_title: As average as you expect – only a spirited comic turn from James saves it from being awful

review_detailed_main: This is what passes for family entertainment these days: a shopping mall security guard has to take charge when the building comes under-siege of post-teenage masterminds (and apparent gymnasts) out to crack the banking codes in the individual stores and collect the money out of the country. Star Kevin James, who also co-produced the film and co-wrote the screenplay, is a handsome, huggable cut-up who knows how to play to the camera; he gets easy laughs with a mean John Candy impersonation, and perhaps slips into Chevy Chase-mode for the 'poignant' moments, but he has no depth. When James is stumbling around drunk or bumping into things, our sympathies don't go out to him--it's just mean-spirited slapstick. The story is comedic "Die Hard" (with a little "Bad Santa" envy) and barely engages the attention. Jayma Mays is the wan salesgirl/love-interest with no personality or background; she's flung together with Paul Blart without us ever seeing how she really feels about him. Blart makes a cute video where he shows off his nerdy-cool moves, but it doesn't win the girl over (does she even see it?). Apparently, because she has big, round eyes and talks like a little girl, Mays is meant to be the perfect woman for our hero. It's an underachiever's idea for an action-comedy-romance, with moronic segues and supporting characters, and a child who keeps yelling "Daddy!" but is never allowed to lend a hand. *1/2 from ****

5/10

"Paul Blart: Mall Cop" is a comedy film released in 2009, directed by Steve Carr and starring Kevin James in the titular role. The movie follows the story of Paul Blart, a mild-mannered and dedicated security guard who finds himself thrust into action when his mall is taken over by a gang of criminals.

Paul Blart (played by Kevin James) is a hardworking but socially awkward single father who takes his job as a security guard at a suburban shopping mall very seriously. Despite his dedication, he is often ridiculed by his peers and longs for respect and recognition.

When a group of highly organized criminals led by Veck Sims (played by Keir O'Donnell) takes control of the mall on Black Friday, Paul finds himself in a position to prove his worth. Armed with his Segway scooter and unwavering determination, Paul takes on the role of an unlikely hero as he attempts to save the day and rescue the hostages, including his teenage crush, Amy (played by Jayma Mays).

The film combines slapstick humor with heartfelt moments as Paul Blart uses his unconventional tactics and resourcefulness to outsmart the criminals and protect the people he cares about. Kevin James delivers a charming and endearing performance as the lovable underdog, earning sympathy and laughter from audiences.

"Paul Blart: Mall Cop" is a feel-good comedy that offers plenty of laughs and an uplifting message about courage, perseverance, and the importance of never giving up. While it may not break new ground in terms of plot or character development, its light-hearted humor and entertaining action sequences make it an enjoyable watch for audiences of all ages.
This is sensational from start to finish. Get it watched.

I enjoyed seeing all the old crew from the "King of Queens" episodes. In fact, it would have been nice to see Jerry Stiller make a small cameo. That would have helped. I just got the feeling from watching some of the scenes, they weren't worked out as well as they should have been. And the script itself needed some over haul, especially the ending. I did laugh at a few pranks, but I didn't connect with the girl who played his daughter, for starters. That was bad casting there. Some scenes appeared rushed, or just didn't fit the flow of the movie. It just seemed the director and producer said to Kevin, "well, it's not great, but , what the heck, it's done, I laughed, let's go to the next shot." We kind of felt like that when we left the theater. "it's not that great, but what the heck. I laughed at a few things. Let's move on." Chances are, if you haven't seen this movie, you'll say the same thing.

It is silly, the underdog finally wins and gets the girl, and there will be a few laughs mixed in throughout. The reason for the low rating is that you don't get anything extra with this one. The story is weak, the action is weak, the jokes are weak, but somehow it all comes together into something respectable (and apparently deserving of a sequel). Kevin James is good at this kind of movie and he plays the character well, but you almost don't need the movie to understand the character with him and I think that is why the movie ultimately falls short. I hope the sequel is better, because there is a lot of opportunity with this one. I would say the battle of the Rainforest Cafe is the best part of this one and even that one fell short of what could have been.

Unable to make the grade as a policeman, Blart has resorted to spending the past ten years as a security guard (or "officer" as he likes to call it) in the local mall. He falls in love with a young saleswoman where he works who sells hair extensions, but he's so clearly out of her league that all he does is make a fool of himself in trying to impress her. But Blart may get a chance to make a hero out of himself when "his" mall becomes overtaken by a group of amateur thieves one evening. About what I expected, which was pretty much nothing. I went to see it because my wife and I wanted to take our 13-year-old niece to the movies and after all, I am a fan of "The King of Queens" show. I didn't think this was too funny, and the character that Kevin James plays is his typical one-note type. If you plan to rent a movie for little kids to enjoy with their grand parents, then you won't be disappointed.

"Paul Blart: Mall Cop" is a masterpiece in the realm of feel-good comedy, and here's why it deserves a solid 10/10.

First, it's a unique blend of heartwarming storytelling and slapstick comedy. Kevin James' portrayal of Paul Blart, the lovable, well-meaning mall cop, is endearing and relatable. Blart is an underdog in every sense-overlooked and underestimated-but his relentless drive to protect his mall showcases the spirit of the everyday hero. This relatable setup makes his triumphs all the more satisfying to watch.

The movie also perfectly balances comedy with genuine warmth. Paul Blart isn't your typical hero, and the film revels in that. His quirks, his Segway, and his sense of duty all make him unforgettable. The humor might seem simple, but it's executed with such charm and sincerity that it elevates the film. Blart's awkward physical comedy and relentless optimism in the face of danger are not only hilarious but deeply humanizing.

Furthermore, the action scenes are unexpectedly entertaining. The mall setting is clever and filled with opportunities for creative physical comedy, which James embraces with enthusiasm. Each set piece feels original, making use of the mall's unique features, from the play areas to the food court. The film makes you root for Blart not just because he's the hero, but because he's so earnestly himself-flaws and all.

Ultimately, "Paul Blart: Mall Cop" isn't just a comedy; it's a feel-good story about perseverance, heart, and heroism in unexpected places. It celebrates the unsung heroes among us, wrapped in a layer of humor that's both accessible and universally funny. A true 10/10, this movie is a joy to watch from start to finish.

review_title: I'm not going to give this film a mall-ing
review_detailed_main:
Kevin James plays Paul Blart, a failed cop who is employed as a mall cop. He's pretty ineffectual at most things, still lives with his Mam, is obese and immature. But, he has a heart of gold. So when some creeps try to rob his mall he springs into action. How will things pan out?

Let's be very clear about this: this is a comedy film, of the style of frat boy/slapstick variety. It's not utterly hilarious, but it is amusing and innocent in a naïve sort of way. There's some scenes that in a more serious film you would cringe at, but this is light entertainment that the whole family can watch, and aside from latent heroism, it also features romance.

It's a far cry from some of the great comedies I've watched but it is non stop fun and sometimes laugh out loud. I really enjoyed it so gave it a solid 6.
